text.p: Here are highlights of stories in Romania's press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:
Business:
ADEVARUL
- The signing of a contract between Romanian aircraft manufacturer IAR SA and U.S. company Bell Helicopter Textron was postponed until after presidential elections.
- The leu currency continues to depreciate and Ion Ghica, president of Banca Comerciala Romana SA, says direct intervention by the central bank had been widely expected.
TINERETUL LIBER
- Farmers managed to sow to wheat 80 percent of planned areas and experts recommend sowing work should be halted and resumed in spring.
CRONICA ROMANA
- State-run steel plant Siderca SA launched a domestic bond issue. The selling price is 18,000 lei per share.
JURNALUL NATIONAL
- Another 50 companies will join trading on the over-the-counter (OTC) market this week.
LIBERTATEA
- Negotiations between Swiss investor Winlook Management Zurich and troubled Banca Dacia Felix SA were halted and are expected to resume after the presidential polls on Sunday.
CURIERUL NATIONAL
- A new investment fund -- Retcon -- started operating. The fund, the first to open after upsets in the funds sector earlier this year, is administered by Pact Invest SA.
General:
ROMANIA LIBERA
- President Ion Iliescu's campaign is offensive to Romanian voters as it assumes they are stupid, former dissident Doina Cornea said.
- The newspaper publishes a two-page report on fraud cases allegedly condoned by Iliescu.
- Democratic Convention (CDR) presidential candidate Emil Constantinescu pledged not to allow dismissals for political reasons.
- Hundreds of thousands of voters were not include on electoral lists for Novemver 3 polls, the LADO human rights group said. The elections were improperly conducted, it said.
- National Unity Party leader Gheorghe Funar said he would support Constantinescu in the presidential run-off.
- Romania's five liberal parties are looking at merging in the first half of 1997.
ADEVARUL
- An "attempted coup" to remove the leader of the Orthodox Church (BOR) was only a diversion, Patriarch Teoctist, head of BOR, said.

- The Social Democratic Union (USD) and its presidential candidate, former Prime Minister Petre Roman, had the most attractive electoral campaign, says a poll by the Acadaemy's Institute for Sociology.
- The CDR and USD are to hold joint electoral rally in centre Bucharest on Wednesday.
EVENIMENTUL ZILEI

- Iliescu lost his temper during a weekend rally and his attitude does not help national reconciliation, analyst Ion Cristoiu says in an editorial. He says Iliescu's campaign speeches unnecessarily excite both his supporters and those of his rival and could lead to radical intolerance, social unrest and even civil war.
- Italian prosecution phonetaps show Romania's involvement in illegal arms dealing.
- The USD started campaigning across the country in support of Constantinescu for the run-off.
- The Socialist Labour Party, the remnants of Romania's former Communist party, will not support Constantinescu.
JURNALUL NATIONAL
- Romania spends 4.5 million lei per year to treat a child with AIDS and 5.4 million for an adult. Children infected with the HIV virus need an annual 2.0 million, adults 1.6 million.
COTIDIANUL
- The newspaper lists eight parties backing Constantinescu in the second round of presidential polls. It says Iliescu is playing a nationalist tune in his campaign.
CRONICA ROMANA
- A family needs at least 16 million lei to furnish an apartment.
CURIERUL NATIONAL
- The Hungarian Democratic Union will be part of the government, Constantinescu said.
- 32 new cases of hepatitis were registered in Bucharest.
LIBERTATEA
- Some 60 percent of parliament members have changed after November 3 polls.
- Italian and German smuggling networks buy kidneys and other organs for some $2,500 each and sell them 10 times more.
VOCEA ROMANIEI
- Constantinescu was a Communist party member for 25 years. ($=3,452 lei) -- Bucharest Newsromm 40-1 3120264
